Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Large-Strain Deformation of Polymeric Gels: Non-linearity, Instability, and Fracture
Award.AbstractNarration:
TECHNICAL SUMMARY:

This project is focused on the deformation behavior of swollen polymer gels under different conditions as a function of their microstructure. The outcome of large-strain deformation of a swollen gel depends on many factors such as molecular architecture, elastic modulus, viscoelasticity and poroelasticity, and length scales relevant to the process. Specific technical goals include: (a) To establish a relationship between molecular architecture, macroscopic mechanical properties, and large-strain deformation behavior of swollen polymer gels. (b) To develop new measurement platforms for characterizing these gels during large-strain deformation processes. (c) To implement a computational framework for describing the deformation process.

To determine the similarities and differences in deformation behavior, a variety of gels formed through covalent, ionic, and physical bonding and consisting of both synthetic and biological polymers, will be considered. This work aims to provide: (a) enhanced insights into gel structure formation at the molecular level, (b) improved understanding of gel deformation as a function of polymer architecture and gel structure, (c) advancement and development of measurement platforms necessary to characterize these materials, (d) a novel computational framework to describe an experimental observation and to predict an outcome for real-life applications, and (e) unifying principles based on this knowledge to design new gels.


NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY:

The project aims to achieve fundamental understanding of the deformation behavior of polymeric gels, and will also be relevant to any soft materials. Polymer gels are used in many applications ranging from bioimplants to tissue scaffolds to oil recovery to drug delivery. Accordingly, this CAREER project will impact the materials/polymer-science, chemical engineering, and biomedical disciplines.

This program is also designed to have an impact on the education and future careers of middle/high-school, undergraduate, and graduate students. The educational and outreach component of this program focuses on three segments: (a) incorporation and further development of course modules on polymer science and soft polymeric materials, (b) involvement of undergraduate students in results-driven research activities, and (c) inspiring middle and high school students to pursue education in STEM majors through laboratory demonstrations and participations in small research projects. To encourage the participation of a broader population in scientific research, the PI plans to recruit graduate students, undergraduate students, and high/middle-school participants from diverse populations, including women and underrepresented minorities.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
Polymer gels are being used or have potential applications in many areas including in food materials,  bioimplants, tissue engineering, drug delivery vehicles, and soft robots/machines. In many of these applications, polymer gels are subjected to mechanical loading, which can lead to failure of these materials. Therefore, for reliable applications of these materials, it is important to link the failure behavior with their structure over multiple length scales. However, as the gels are wet, soft, and fragile, the characterization of gels is often difficult. In our research, we have selected gels formed by synthetic and biopolymers with both physical and chemical crosslinking and have investigated their structure-property relationship, with particular emphasis on gel responses subjected to large mechanical deformation. These investigations were conducted by adopting and extending the commonly used experimental protocols and developing new tools, both experimental and computational. We have made advances towards linking the gel mechanical properties as a function of their microstructure.

Intellectual Merit:

For physically assembled triblock copolymer organogels in a midblock selective solvent, it has been shown that the interaction between the polymer blocks and the chosen solvent dictates the self-assembly process. Structure formation of these gels and the change of those structures as a function of oscillatory strain have been captured using scattering techniques. Similar to biological networks, strain-stiffening response has been observed for the gels with shorter midblocks, and such responses can be attributed to the finite extensibility of those shorter midblock. For longer midblock length and at higher polymer concentration, the midblocks can form entanglement. The presence of entanglement has been attributed to the rate-dependent mechanical properties. We have theoretically estimated the fracture energy release rate of these gels,  linking the midblock stretching, friction that the endblocks are subjected to as those are pulled out of the glassy aggregates, and enthalpic penalty associated with non-preferable interaction between the endblocks and the solvent. 

In addition, we have investigated alginate hydrogels with both ionic and chemical crosslinks. Alginate is a commonly used biopolymer in the biomedical and food industries. We have uniquely captured strain-stiffening and negative normal stress responses of these gels during shear-deformation, which have not been widely reported earlier for polysaccharide gels. The change in gel microstructure because of the type of crosslinking has shown to affect the strain-stiffening behavior.

Broader Impacts:

The project provided numerous training and professional development opportunities for the graduate and undergraduate students, postdoctoral researchers, and the PI. The fundamental scientific understanding regarding the gel structure-property relationship and the characterization frameworks that have developed in this project can be directly employed to other soft materials. The graduate students and the PI  have widely disseminated research results through conference presentations and proceedings, and peer-reviewed journal publications. The research results have also been incorporated into undergraduate and graduate education. During the course of this project, our research group has participated in several outreach activities targeting the K-12 students, for example, Girl Scout Day. The goal of these outreach activities is motivating these students to pursue higher education in STEM fields by introducing them to the various aspects of polymer science and soft materials, such as the concepts of macromolecules, both synthetic and biological origin, and mechanics of gels through simple experiments.


Last Modified: 07/30/2020
Modified by: Santanu Kundu
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Polymer gels are being used or have potential applications in many areas including in food materials, bioimplants, tissue engineering, drug delivery vehicles, and soft robots/machines. In many of these applications, polymer gels are subjected to mechanical loading, which can lead to failure of these materials. Therefore, for reliable applications of these materials, it is important to link the failure behavior with their structure over multiple length scales. These investigations were conducted by adopting and extending the commonly used experimental protocols and developing new tools, both experimental and computational. We have made advances towards linking the gel mechanical properties as a function of their microstructure. Intellectual Merit: For physically assembled triblock copolymer organogels in a midblock selective solvent, it has been shown that the interaction between the polymer blocks and the chosen solvent dictates the self-assembly process. We have uniquely captured strain-stiffening and negative normal stress responses of these gels during shear-deformation, which have not been widely reported earlier for polysaccharide gels. The change in gel microstructure because of the type of crosslinking has shown to affect the strain-stiffening behavior. The fundamental scientific understanding regarding the gel structure-property relationship and the characterization frameworks that have developed in this project can be directly employed to other soft materials. The graduate students and the PI have widely disseminated research results through conference presentations and proceedings, and peer-reviewed journal publications. The research results have also been incorporated into undergraduate and graduate education. During the course of this project, our research group has participated in several outreach activities targeting the K-12 students, for example, Girl Scout Day. The goal of these outreach activities is motivating these students to pursue higher education in STEM fields by introducing them to the various aspects of polymer science and soft materials, such as the concepts of macromolecules, both synthetic and biological origin, and mechanics of gels through simple experiments.
